Taste - not bad, really, the scorched character from the nose is replaced by a light honey-sweet oat grain taste and some dry floral hops (faint, but there) - this is actually nicely malty.  Mouthfeel is lightly flat, lightly syrupy, decent body - apart from the quick finish and the odd nose, not too bad for a eurolager.
bottle. bright yellow. big white head. high carp. bitter with hops and malt. thin pallete.
Golden clear. White head. Grassy and malty aroma. Rather thin palate........

my first bohemian pilsener.  not a very well regarded category i see.  and with good reason.  this was sharply bitter.  so bitter it even ruined the nose.  lagering yeasts actually dominated the flavor.  body is pretty pathetic, this is like all those czech/polish beers: utterly one-dimensional.

50 cl bottle. No yeast at the bottom. Golden clear colour with a wonderful white head. Sweet malty aroma with a touch of hops. Sweet flavour of malt combined with a lightful touch of fruit from the hops. Ends up little but nice bitter.

Bottle 50cl. Poured light gold in colour, with a small, fizzy head that quickly disappeared. Highly carbonated. Vague aroma of hops and grass. Sharp hoppy almost metallic flavour, with a bitter hoppy finish. Tasty, flavoursome lager.
Pale, yellow, clear with thin ringing white head.  Aroma is lager light corn.  Flavor is light malt, grass.  Thin.

Appears a light gold with a small white film that is scattered about the glass.
Smell is of corn syrup, flowers, honey, and slight maltiness.
Taste is of the same aromas.  Nothing great jumping out of this.
Mouthfeel is sugary water with slight fizz.
Drinkability…nothing great…what’s the point of the yeast in this one?  It’s just like diluted sugar  water.

Froma can, in a trade with oh6gdx. The body was dark gold. The aroma was lightly grassy with a little a cheese funk. The taste was bitter bread crust with some light grass. There was a also a smooth green bell pepper spice.
Thanks to weeare138 for this Norristown special.  Pours a tranlucent golden with a small white head.  Aroma was grassy, sweet and malty. Ice tea.  Flavor of the same. Very sweet and watery.
Bottle shared courtesy of weeare138 (thanks!). Pured a medium golden colro wtih an averaged sized white head. Aromas and tastes of corn, malty sweetness and some wheat. Boring.

Not bad, but it sort of has a bit of an adjuncty feel to it. Lots of bready malt in the aroma and flavour, with a lot of sweetness in both. A bit of a metallic twang too. Pales in comparison to the Bernard I had the other day...

A light golden amber colour with a light effevescence, a very clean, and slight aroma of wheat and hops, there is also a touch of liquorice. the taste is again of dry hops, and the wheaty aspect comes through again. the aftertaste is very light, with only a little dryness on the palate.
Clear golden with a thick white head that vanish quickly. Aroma is hoppy and floral. The taste is light, some hops, very drinkable. Nothing wrong but nothing special either.
Interesting, it’s no a bad one. BUt it has a pumpkin after taste that I did not get at all, but I liked it.

There is a wonderful tale told in Michael Jackson’s Beer Hunter Series about The Good Soldier Svejk. Svejk for Czech beer drinkers, is a national hero of sorts. As the story goes, Svejk failed to join his regiment. When asked what happened, Svejk replied: "It happened to me that I drank one beer after another." Kozel might have been the beer that caused Svejk to forget about reporting back for duty, and continue to drink beer. This is a fantastic Czech Pilsner, it very clean, malty, hoppy, and so, so drinkable.

Kozel pours to a beautiful, bright, deep golden color, with a nice white head, and a soft carbonation. The nose on this beer is very inviting. Very fragrant Saaz hop aromas coupled with some good pilsner malt aroma, and a touch of DMS(sulphur like aroma) flood the nose. The palate is crisp and clean. Wonderful pilsner malt flavors with a smooth, round, body. This beer finishes with a nice hop bite up front, then dries with a snappy, grassy, bitter hop finish. This is a drinking beer. I could lose a day, or a weekend in a tavern in Prague drinking glass after glass of this beer. With pilsners as good as this, can you really blame Svejk for not joining his regiment? I guess the moral of the story is, if your going to drink a beer as fantastic as Kozel, don’t make any other plans. Match this with roasted chicken, or grilled fish.
Very good Lager. Taste is mild but colourfull. Maybe there are better beers in this kind, but Kozel has a great if not the best balance.

Pours a clear golden color, the head is white and initially has a medium thickness but slowly diminishes. The aroma reveals hay and noble hops, it is gentle. The flavor is good, fruits (berries) flirt with noble hops on a stack of hay, the flirt finishes with bitteness. The body has a medium to full thickness, the texture is creamy and the carbonation moderate. I didn’t think I would really appreciate this beer but it is a pleasant surprise.

Medium and compact foam, discreet duration. Yellow gold color, limpid and medium fizzy. Determined alcohol and malty scent, unusual for one Czech beer. Much prickly and racy taste; enough determined malty and hoppy notes, overbearing and long-lasting bitter. Elevated alcoholic perception. Balanced end.

Overall a great great beer.  Goes down even better after trying other, inferior, beers!  It is the best medium beer I have tried, better than Staropramen and even Pilsner!  I prefer Czech beer, in general, but this one easily takes the cake.  A number of people I know think Staropramen’s "Granat" is better but I don’t agree.  I also like Kozel because it has less of a bite.
A nice solid lager. Nothing too special. Malty on the nose. Pours golden amber with reasonable foamy head. Nice mix of malt sweetness and hoppy bitterness. Good beer.
Bottle, soft malty lager. Good Czech style perhaps a bit lighter than Budvar but still an enjoyable brew, sweet malt and fruity hops on the finish.

I enjoyed the dark Kozel a lot, so my hopes were fairly high. I wasn’t disappointed: clear, deep gold, generous foamy head that leaves a lacy glass. Solid malty nose, well rounded palate with all of the things you expect to taste in a good quality pale lager-- a malty, bitter, and refreshing mouthful.

500ml bottle. Darkish gold with thin tight white head. Bit of a sickly pale malt aroma, but ok in mouth and then some hop bitterness.   Not overly wonderful, but for some reason I really like.  Has some biscuity malt too.
Bottled.  Good, simple, clean tasty Pilzen with a clear Saaz flavour.  Colour is golden orange, head is thick but disappears way too quickly, though.
Bottle.  1-2cm white head dissipates quickly.  Aroma has very slight floral hint.  Taste is somewhat sweet; light, and refreshing.  An average pils; easy to drink but not outstanding in any area.
Bottle. Golden colour with 1cm white head. Malt and floral hops in the aroma. Sweet, grassy, hoppy taste, with some light malts and a fairly bitter finish. Medium bodied. A pretty good pilsner.

Is this a lager or a pilsener? Bottle. Bland lager aroma. Clear gold body with steady and wide visible carbonation. Thin white head with excellent lace. Head is mostly diminishing. Just prior to having this beer I had a Zlatorog Premium (Slovenia), which was maltier, fuller bodied and with more bite. This is smoother, creamier frankly, more innocuous. But, I agree, with a point more for appearance and a point omre for palate, Kozel Premium beats it out slightly, although not sure that I would choose it over the Zlatorog. This is a very basic beer that may go well with spicy food but that really doesn’t provide more functionality than that.

Medium gold in colour with lots of carbonation. Good aromas of honey-like malt, and both grassy and floral hops. That floral note is especially nice. The flavor is a bit of a letdown after the aroma, with more corse grassy notes entering the lightly malted mix, but the bitterness is at a good level for this style of beer. Overall, a fairly good pilsner.

On draught at U cerneho vola in Prague: Golden colour, medium-sized firm white froth, clear but very shy malty and slightly hoppy nose, sweetish and slightly hoppy taste, distinctive  light hoppy aftertaste. Good, but not overwhelming.......

Bottle at Atlas One Café. What’s with the 3.34 average? Man, you guys are easy to please. Pours a bubbly amber with an average size fizzy white head. Very, very mild aroma of yeast, malt and citrus. Flavour consists of grain, malt and sugar and is also very mild. I must have got the one bottle they left the hops out of? It has a slightly unpleasant aftertaste. Overall, another bland and boring "International Lager". Yawn.

On tap in Telč:



The Lure:
Everlasting foam covers grain, bread and hay. All in all, this hardly smells anything.



The Festivities:
Minute hay and frail herbal hops make up a perfectly inoffensive, well-brewed, pilsener. Suggestions of bitterness appear through the feisty carbonation, which by the way helps the mouthfeel. Refreshing when cold, but this is filtered mass appeal. This is the white bread of beer; good with sandwiches but...



Transcendence:
At festivities you can drop half your pint and not care much.

Pours a golden colour with a foamy head and a floral, grassy nose.  Good carbonation with a bitter malt taste and a nice dry finish.  I like the label, a goat enjoying a beer.  Hey, if it’s good enough for the goat... (500ml bottle)
Bottle.  Pours clear gold with thin white head.  Balanced aroma of hops and malt.  More malt flavors than most Czech pilsners, but balanced and somewhat dry.  Tough to find on tap in Prague.
Bottled. Clear golden colour. Medium to small head. Grassy, sweet hoppiness in the nose. Lightly malty and medium sweet for a pilsner. Light to medium dry, hoppy finish. A good one.
(Bottle 33 cl) Deep golden with a rather small head. Very soft and aromatic from the quality hops. Rather soft hoppiness. Nice full body with lots of malt-sweetness. Typical Czech premium.
Bottled, served at Standing Order (JDW) Derby. Good rounded maltiness, pleasent enough but nothing to fall out of bed for.
500ml brown bottle. Deep bright gold. Dense fluffy head. Light carbonation. Fresh malty aroma, touch of Euro hops. Flavour echos the aroma, malty and trace bitterness. Nice smoothness.
One of the better Czechs, albeit a bit hoppier than I really like.  Good cold, even better when cold, out of a tap, in a bar in a backwater Czech industrial town (where I had it first)
Bottled. Deep golden colour, minor white head. Malty nose with hints of caramel. Wellbalanced flavour of sweet malt, caramel and hops. Bitterish and dry finish.

Light aroma that gets gradually worse. This is the third or fourth Bohemian in a row that looks exactly the same.  I couldn’t tell you what make this "Premium" - it really isn’t better than most of the other Bohemian. Has a very dry finish. It’s style percentage rating is too high - the Staro- Bohemians are better.

Pale golden beer with a thick white head.  Sticky lacing.  Sweet pale malt, spicy and floral hop aroma.  Light caramel and a fat maltiness.  Flavour is well-balanced, sweet malt, spicy Saaz and a fairly smooth bitter finish.  A well-made, if standard, pils.
Had this a couple of times. A tue Boh-Pil much better then most. And the logo looks good.

Poured a burnished gold colour with an impressive 3cm foaming head. Left plenty of lacing. Looked great but the light aroma disappointed. Some lemon citrus, peaches and faint malt. Fruity hops and plenty of malt on the tongue and a moderately dry finish. Smooth customer, thin in the frame but spritely. Solid drinking but by no means a classic of this style. (Bottle, 4.8%, Best Before 12/7/05)

Appealing golden-tan pour. Coarse carbonation, uneven lacing. Fresh cotton and malt aroma. Supple lager, great fresh malt, nicely balanced and swirled with hops. Light citrus and complex grain finish. Sweet, yet a little dry. Sustains on the palate. Very drinkable and smooth!

Very refreshing. 

Very nice floral hoppy aroma.  Goes down smooth and - like a good pilsener - leaves a nice bitterness behind on the tongue.

A good solid beer - ideal with Indian food - one that I will be buying again.

This one I used to drink quite often when I was younger. Sceptical that I might not like it now, I gave it another try! Tasted from the bottle, it poured a brilliant deep gold, with a slowly forming dense white head, that lasted and laced down the stein. Aroma was floral and dry, leafy,with a little sweetness to balance. In the mouth, to begin with, the delicate floral hops dominated, with an offset of honey malt tones in front and mid-palate, finishing with a bitter-sweet swallow. Towards the end of the glass, though, the hops faded and the malt dominated, making for a refreshing and balanced-out lager, with medium carbonation and a good overall mouth feel. Still enjoyable now, as it was when I was younger!!!

Fizzy dark gold with a filmy white head that forms a nice spotty ring.  Very nice aroma of noble hops and sweet malt.  Flavour is full of those components of the aroma plus a very small amount of diacetyl butterscotch.  Gentle bitterness that’s in good balance with the malt and hops with little aftertaste.  Medium body and pleasantly carbonated.  Very good.

Citrus-lemon and cereal malt aroma with some strong peppery spiciness and earthy notes to the hops.  Clear golden coloured body is topped by thin but lasting white head.  Cereal-like malt flavour is quite sweet with a fairly spicy/earthy hop flavour and crisp finishing bitterness that lasts in the mouth.  Refreshing light-medium body with strong effervescence.  Bottle.
Nice enough. Quite a surprisingly strong bitter aftertaste. Plenty of malt.
nice golden color, with a decent head. perfectly balanced rich malty flavour and medium bitterness. a real surprise, but it was excellent.
Golden with a small head.  Aromas are grain with sweetened lemon and lime - odd but welcome.  Flavours are grain and citrus fruit.  Metallic hops on the finish.  Pretty solid.

Bottle at JDW High Wycombe. Absolutely nothing I hadn’t tried on draught anywhere in the town centre, so I had this. 4.8% ABV. Sweet and malty lager with a bitter bite. Not so great but drinkable. Notes of honey & sugar. No complexities in the flavour, simply pedestrian drinking.
Golden and brilliant appearance in the glass. Modest head. Moderate hops flavor, with a taste similar to Pilsner Urquell, but far superior in overall craftsmanship. Clean aftertaste. Wonderful brew.
Clear gold with red hue & big fluffy white head. Sweet, grassy aroma. Typical Czech pils. Nice clean maltiness w/ light bitterness to round it off.

This is a great Boh in that it gives off the impression of honey and has the taste of it as well.  While Urquell builds up to the great finish, this one hits quite immediately.  Not the best, but better than usual for sure.

Bottled (BB 02/2005)

Golden honey color with big white head and lots of lace. Metallic, fruity and slightly hoppy aroma. Medium malty body. Clean, balanced, fruity but not enough hops for this style, more like a premium lager.
A solid pilsener. Hoppy aroma, grassy. Pours a golden yellow, mid-range carbonation. Nice malt body, crisp hops in the finish.
Beautiful golden body with solid head. Nice malty nose. Flavor has this nice czech hoppy taste wich makes this a very refreshing beer.

Nice golden body topped with a thick bubbly head. Good malty nose with strong bready hints. Taste is sharp, fresh and hoppy, and the bitter final is more than decent. This is one of the top-sellers in Czech Republic and Slovakia, and it is a very good example of bohemian pilsner. I even prefer this to the famous Budejovicky Budvar.

Bottled (filtered?). Pale yellow with natural head. Good ’soft’ pilsner, full of warm malty flavours overlaid with a hoppy bitterness. Floral qualities show through with an orange fruitiness. Good quality Pilsner.

A truly good, authentic commercial Czech Pilsner. This is the type of Pilsner Beck’s  wished they could produce. They can’t, this brew took time. Brew time and cellar time. The quality of ingredients and process are there on this Pilsner. Soft barley and malt tastes balanced with those heavenly saaz bitters. A great example of Czech pilsen style lagers. This one has a distinguishing quality though. It has everything required of a good Pilsner, flowery hopping evident to the nose and palate, sharp crisp start, tart/malty/grassy in the mouth dry finish except, this one has no lingering "tinny" taste to the tongue from the saaz hops. I liked this Pilsner very much . The only draw back is the price. $2.85 per 500mil bottle. I was surprised this beer was so fresh tasting, date code was near expired and it sat unrefrigerated on the LCBO  shelf. A “must try” if you like Pilsners.
Can - re-rating.  Slightly sweet malt aroma - very nice.   Medium tan color with ample light tan head.  NIce moderate hops flavor with hops and slightly sweet finish.

Another fine example of Czech Pils. It rates along side of Staropromen, Czechvar and Urqiel. Lots of flavour, good body, lasting after-taste. Great beer to have with a meal, or just sitting around watching a film.

One is starting to suspect that the takeover by SAB has made this more and more similiar to Pilsener Urquell by the day. Same aroma, very similar body (though more malt perception IMO). I always toss up between this and PU at the bottleshop. I usually grab this If I’m feeling greedy because you get more from the 500ml bottle. It’s a very good honest drop. But never tastes the same in Australia as it does in it’s homeland where it always seems to posess a little something extra.
Bottle. Some saazy hop aroma but kind of subdued. Firm slightly chewy malt with lots of bitterness. A touch to much carbonation spoils the otherwise excellent body.
Dry aromas.  Smooth finish and fine balance. Tallie bottle is a plus.  Any beer with a black goat and stein as a logo must be good.
Pale golden colour with a fizzy white head. Mostly bready and cereal aroma and flavours, with fruity notes. Medium bodied, slightly sticky mouthfeel.

This pilsner/lager???? poured a amber colour with a yeasty spore head. Scents include a hint of orange citrus with almost a spiced corn scent. Slightly metallic odour. Initial taste was a little yeasty and sour with a bitter finish. Palate had a lingering bitter aftertaste that wasn't too bad. Nothing special.

A very satisfying and refreshing pilsner. Light gold body, and an enjoyable sweet aroma. A tad bitter, but I can also get some sweetness on the finish? Malty sweetness to be exact. Nice brew though....good for a BBQ or hanging with your amigos.

Vibrant & clear golden colour with a moderate white head. Fresh and slightly fruity aroma. Nice and well-trounded maltiness in the flavour, with mildly bitter and fruity hops in the finish. Decent and refreshing.

I've had some luck with beers with goats/sheep holding on to a glass of beer, on the label. Pours gold, lacey foamy head. Sweet hoppy nose. Syrupy honey qualities. Grassy. Elements of toasted hop/malt. Finishes crisp and bitter. It's pretty run of the mill.

Pours clear gold with high carbonation. Nice small tight white bubbled head with decent retention. Initial smell upon opening of stale hops. After letting settle for a minute clean pils malt starts to dominate. Bit of grassy saaz aroma there too. Thin mouthfeel, though smooth. Sweet tart start with a crisp tart bitter mid. Lovely hoppy aftertaste. Bit of lemon there too. Overall quite a clean refreshing beer. Pils isnt really my style but I enjoyed this.

Bottled.  A superior pilsner.  Notes of banana in both the nose and the palate.  Quite heavy but very smooth and drinkable.Score 3.3
Subsequent rating scored 3.1. Average becomes 3.2
They say it is smooth, which it is, but it too hard to drink for a pilsener for mine. too heavy in feel going down, sits on the tongue too long. Needs a kick to help it down.
A great Czech Pils.  Nice sweet bitter malt flavour and aroma.  Not saazy like the Urquell but who cares, doesn’t seem to have diacetyl.  Give me more please.

(Bottled) Golden color with a big, diminishing, lacy head. Quite malty, moderately hoppy and fruity, slightly honey-sugary aroma. Quite malty, somewhat fruity and sweet, aromatic-hopped, but also bitter flavor with a very subtle, buttery finish. Medium-bodied, soft and smooth-carbonated, oily palate. Quite an enjoyable, very smooth and easily drinkable pilsener.

I'm not sure about this beer. Pours with a nice head but that doesn't last long. Some floral and honey aromas. Flavour seems to indicate a significant proportion of cane sugar, lacking malt, some hop flavour and mildly bitter finish. I think I've enjoyed it more other times I've had it.
RR: A bit better this time. Caramel aroma, some soft maltiness, but the metallic hop flavour still annoys me a lot.
A decent pils, with good malts and some hops at the finish.  Has an earthy/toffee kind of quality that I can't quite describe effectively.  I'd love to try this off the tap sometime.

The pour a translucent gold color with the head portly in size and the texture semi-creamy, bright white in color as it dissipates a fine sheet of lace is left to seal off the glass. Nose is dominated by the malt, somewhat sweet and a citrus like crispness, start nicely malted and sweet with the top fair to middling in its feel. Finish has a light acidity with the hops moderate in their spiciness, drinkable but just another average lager.
Aroma was all hops and malt. Perfectly clean yellow colour. Flavour was still lightly malty with maybe a touch of caramel and fruit (peaches I thought) with a great non sticky hop aftertaste.

Malts dominate giving body and flavour.Caramel
tastes blend with the malts to produce a pilsener that stands out from the crowd.After a while a slight bitterness surfaces.All round a very desirable beer.

Golden colour with a tinge of red, pours a decent head but doesn't seem to last. Not a lot of aroma but some hop characters. Malty taste with just a hint of bitterness on the finish. Went down easy enough.
Soft hoparoma. Hoppy, grassy flavor. Bitter, hay-like aftertaste. Not the best of Czech pilseners, but decent quality.

This reminded me of Urquell, which is always a good thing, but there's enough going on to make it distinctive all by itself. A little sweeter yet not overpoweringly so. Nice appearance as well. All in all a nice package for a pilsner.

Well when drinking this I starting off comparing it to PU, but they are nothing alike - PU has a bite, I found kozel to be generous on the malt (a honey light malt)and to go down very smoothly.  Very happy with this effort.  cheers
Dark amber color with a nice creamy head. Aroma is clearly toffee, sweet and very nice. Flavor is a little thin, some citrus. Almost no bitterness.
Clear yellow with a moderate head. Fruity flowery (grassy?) aroma. Hoppy bite to it. Not bad, not really to my taste though.

Golden color, not so stable head. Slightly malty aroma. Weak body with malt flavour. Not as rich as Budweiser Budvar or Staropramen. Hops are missing. Nice malt aftertaste. Nothing great but drinkable. Smooth on the palate.

Tasted in "U Kozla", Prague. Deep golden color and classic mountainous snow-white head. Aroma is fruity and malty, Palate is wonderfully citric, lemonish with hints of caramel malt and bread. Dry and slightly fruity (apricots, peaches) finish.

Can
Blond color. Light malty aroma, ordinary taste, quite bitter.

Re-rate: Much less sweet and more hoppy than i first thought it was. Fine pilsener. Original rate: Golden/orange coloured, small head. Sweet aroma, bit weird. Pretty sweet for a pilsener, not balanced. As caesar, i prefer the svetly.
Orange color. Aroma is sweet like paint. Very sweet and not bitter pils. I prefer the svetly version.
Tasted at 5C.  Ricj golden colour.   No head.  Sweet scent.  Taste is slightly sweet (less sweet than the scent, however) with slight grassy taste and bitter finish.
Smells a bit sweetish, almost like a weiss, but the flavour has well-balanced maltiness with a very bitter finish. Mine was a bit flat, so I'll rerate later.
A beautiful Golden beer with an almost golden aroma, tall white head and refreshing balanceed hop and malt taste. Thumbs up, well worth it

This is an easy drinking beer in a typical Bohemian style. Closer to a Budvar than a Pilsner Urquell in hop profile but one of those soft pils with a good balance of hop and malt. Very accessible for the average lager drinker
Bottled. Bright golden colour, with a bold white head that persisted throughout. Sweet hope aroma, with a smooth malt pils taste. Very smooth indeed.
Some pech in the aroma and a lot of bitterness. The palate is a bit sandish.

Xtal clear medium gold with large lasting yellow head. Faint stale hops and malt with hint of egg white aroma. Medium thin smooth body. Medium mild hoppy bitter start with some sweeter  biscuity and fruity malt kicking in towards the middle. Medium bitter hop finish moving to a mellow sweeter malty after taste. Nice!
Bottled: Golden coloured. White quickly diminsihing head. Aroma is sweet, fruity and light hoppy.  Very smooth flavour. Some fruit accents. Light bitter in the end.
well balanced Czech pilsener providing sweet and dry notes.  Light and refreshing, on the tongue, with a nice bitter aftertaste.
Nice and clean pils with a golden yellow color.  Nice happy flavor with hints of sweetness.  Good texture and finish.  Nice beer.
Smooth and easy is the best way I can describe this beer. Not as good as Urquell, but never the less a great Pils.
Gotta love it. Unique hoppy taste. Smells great, looks great. A solid, good brew. One of my favourites.
Very clean appereance, quite good head. Another great quality Bohemian pilsener with a hoppy taste. Excellent!
Easy to drink. Nothing special. Medium bitterness and a developed aroma. There are hundreds like Kozel.
A good hop bite but left a strange oily feeling on the tongue. Not too impressive.
slightly bitter finish. the pour isn't too appealing. tastes quite nice going down.
Fine Czech pilsener. Nice aroma - like grass from Czech - Moravian hills. Light bitterness. Good aftertaste. Very palate.
Clear gold w/ reddish hue & big fluffy white head. Sweet, grassy aroma. Light, refreshing palate. Typical Czech pils. Nice clean maltiness w/ light bitterness to round the finish.
Bottled(500ml). -the best Czech's beer, smooth bitter taste, very good aftertaste
Nice amber pilsner. Good size and consistency of almonde coloured head and great aroma. For a pilsener this beer is very well brewed. Excellent finish...

can 500 ml 
 
Appearance:  crystal clear with deep golden appearance. Large fine head of good density. Some lace in form of a ring. 4-
Nose:   soft nose , wet grassy hints , grainy with dusty top. Sweet golden malt.6+
Flavor/Palate :  medium light bodied. Smooth bit oily grainy sweet character with leafy bitter top. Proper yet not as smooth as some Czech brews go. Bit light on malt. Late bitter hop finish.
smooth and yes bitter, however it had a strange aftertaste to it. but the initial taste was enough to give it a good rating. I would buy this one again.

Beautiful aromas of sharp malt with hints of  doughy bread smells. Pillowy head dissapates but leaves a good filigree. Sharp maltiness is well balanced and strong, astringent finish puckers the mouth slightly. Rough around the edges comparded to Urquell or Budvar, but a fine beer none the less. Will try again.

A decent Bohemian lager. I am not a lover of lagers, but I''ve yet to find a Czech lager that ends up down the plug hole. This is a firm bodied and very smooth pilsener, with touches of polished honey. The balance between bitter and sweet is so perfect, the whole thing so well structured, that drinking is easy, pleasurable and very satisfying. There are little dots of lemon, moments of grassy honey, and a long lingering, gentle Saaz finish.

I'm having this to wash the taste(or lack of taste) of a coors light out of my mouth, so maybe I'm biased, but this seems a delightful lager.  nice golden colour with a dense white head.  doughy malt aroma and flavour.  nice rounding hops.
Really good pilsener, one of the TOP10 I would even say. ...................

This is a very good pils. It has a strong malty aroma.  It is smooth on the palate and has a fairly pungeant, pronounced hop (saaz) bitterness with a faint saaz hop flavour and little or no hop finish.  It is a well rounded pils with no flaws and no twist.
Great pilsner! Good taste & nice body! One of the best!.....................
A good head produced for a lager, makes for a good initial appearance.  The aroma and flavour is slightly sweet. Overall a pleasant tasting continental beer.

Pale, minimal head, non-lasting. Flavour quite fruity, apples, honey... sweetness lingers on the palate far more than any bitterness, though not unpleasant. Truly easy to drink, an excellent  Czech Pils, as expected from Kozel.
yes one of the great beers of the world. the best way to enjoy this beer though is when in the czech republic on draft and dont forget there dark beer
One of the great beers in the world. While visiting Prague, do not forget to drink one of the tap.
A well-balanced Czech pilsener, no more, no less............................
Light golden color, some head.  Green apple, grassy, some hops in the nose.  Light bitter hops, nice long palate.  Solid example.
Sweet malty aroma. Golden colour, big head. Big malty flavour, nice bitterness. Fresh, crisp with tongue tingle. Very good pilsner

One of the premium Czech pilseners - My dad's favorite. Not as characteristic as Urquell or Czechvar. Its Appearance is a pleasure to the eye while the smooth body accompanied by a well-balanced taste seduces your tongue. A somewhat of bitter aftertaste. Thumbs high up!!!

great label. when good beer drinkers-- who tipped thier waitresses and were kind to animals-- reach the great beyond, they might be greeted by the velke popovice goat   bringing us the enormous ceremonial welcoming draft. if it's a kozel, i won't complain. it's a thin canary color with a bit of innocuous particulate matter, clean head and robust, almost wheat-beer like citrus honey aroma with biscuity malt in back. very convivial sweetness with creamy palate; good bitter hops carry their weight too.  refreshing summer bier.
